title: Woman learns she was stolen at birth after selfie with ‘identical’ schoolfriend
text:
The two friends innocently took the selfie without realising they were long lost half-sisters

A woman’s world was turned upside down when a selfie with a schoolmate led to her discovering she had been stolen from hospital as a baby.

Miché Solomon, 21, from Cape Town, South Africa, was stunned when she took a picture with Cassidy Nurse.

The then 17-year-old student was told the girl looked ‘identical’ to her the pair became inseparable ever since, completely unaware they were actually half-sisters.

But the truth unravelled when Cassidy showed her parents a selfie of them both.

It led to Miché eventually discovering Lavona Solomon, the woman who raised her, was not her real mother.

Celeste Nurse outside the Western Cape High Court during sentencing of Lavona Solomon (Picture: Getty/Gallo Images)

She was actually named Zephany Nurse as a baby before she was abducted from Cape Town’s Groote Schuur Hospital in 1997.

When Cassidy’s showed the selfie to mum and dad Morne and Celeste Nurse, they asked when Miché’s birthday was.

Morne then met the girl, who revealed her date of birth, prompting him to go to the police to express his concerns.

Just a few weeks later, Miché was called to the headmasters office and told the shocking truth about her being stolen from hospital.

She told the BBC: ‘I sat there in shock. My life was out of control.’

Miché was sceptical to begin with but she agreed to a DNA test which proved the Nurses were her parents.

Family gather in front of the Nurse residence after finding Zephany (Picture: Getty/Gallo Images)

She was ‘broken’ when police subsequently arrested Solomon and struggled to cope with the idea she was not her real mother.

It is thought Lavona covered up a miscarriage by pretending to carry on the rest of her pregnancy before stealing Zephany from hospital and raising the baby as her own.

The Nurses went on to have three more children but never gave up hope of finding their long lost daughter.

The divorced pair celebrated her birthday every year, completely unaware she lived only 5km from them.

Miché’s said she ‘felt nothing’ for her biological parents, despite an emotional reunion, which she acknowledged would be ‘a shame’ for them given all they had been through.

During her trial in Cape Town, which began in August 2015, Lavona Solomon denied dressing as a nurse to gain access to the maternity ward in April 1997, despite being identified by an eyewitness after her arrest.

Morne and Celeste Nurse embrace each other after court proceedings in Cape Town (Picture: AP)

In an attempt to explain herself, the defendant said a mysterious woman handed Zephany to her at a crowded train station in the city.

But Judge John Hope dismissed this account as a ‘fairytale’ which ‘should be treated with the contempt it deserves’.

She was jailed for 10 years in 2016 for kidnapping, fraud and violating the Children’s Act.

Reflecting on the emotional strain the trial took on her, Miché said she sometimes ‘hated’ her biological parents for taking Solomon away from her.

Lavona Solomon was jailed for 10 years for kidnapping, fraud and violating the Children’s Act (Picture: Getty/Gallo Images)

She said: ‘I felt like death was happening to me.

‘How am I going to get through life without the mother that I had every day in my life?’

After visiting Solomon in prison, demanding to know why she lied and ‘changed her whole destiny’, she merely replied Miché would know what happened ‘one day’.

But despite the deception and lack of closure, she still visits her in jail and wishes time would ‘hurry up’ towards her release date.
